thread.title: Sculptures 'disappear' from Sir Antony Gormley’s lake installation in Australia
thread.title_full: Sculptures 'disappear' from Sir Antony Gormley’s lake installation in Australia - Telegraph

author: Jonathan Pearlman , Sydney
title: Sculptures 'disappear' from Sir Antony Gormley’s lake installation in Australia
text: At least two sculptures have disappeared from an installation in outback Australia by British artist Sir Antony Gormley, whose internationally renowned work features 51 human-like figurines placed across a remote salt lake. Another of the sculptures has been damaged, with nothing left but a pair of feet. Locals believe that a truck driver may have stolen or damaged one of the steel stick figures, after he became stuck on the lake and used a figurine to help winch the vehicle to safety. The remote inland work, about 500 miles from Perth in Western Australia, attracts visitors from around the world but has proven difficult to protect. Titled Inside Australia, it has been valued at more than £6 million. File photo: Sir Antony Gormley stands with one of his cast iron sculptures Photo: PA • Valuable Banksy artworks lost in Australia as man paints over wall The Art Gallery of Western Australia, which is responsible for the installation, said the sculptures had occasionally been damaged but extra signage installed in 2008 had been largely successful. Art Sculptures ( Inside Australia ) on Lake Ballard by Antony Gormley, Western Australia Photo: Alamy “Given the remoteness of the site, AGWA relies on our collaboration with the local shire, and also helpful visitors, for any information about incidental damage,” a spokeswoman told The Australian. The installation was commissioned by a Perth arts festival in 2003 and then presented by Gormley as a gift to the state for $1. Vehicles are not supposed to drive on Lake Ballard, where Gormley installed his work. A single sculpture was sold in 2008 for about £180,000. Sculpture by Antony Gormley, Inside Australia exhibition, on Lake Ballard, Western Australia Photo: Alamy Greg Dwyer, the local shire president, said authorities did not police the site and were dependent on visitors for information about damaged or stolen pieces, which are spread across six miles of the lake. “It has become an iconic international art site, and we're very proud to have it – it has certainly put Menzies on the map," he told Fairfax Media. Gormley has become famous for his public artworks featuring figurines based on the human body , including Another Place, his collection of 100 iron sculptures now on permanent display at Crosby Beach, near Liverpool. telegraph.co.uk Follow @telegraphnews
